title: Signal in the Code
text:
Welcome 👋






Twelve years ago, two researchers proposed a provocative idea: that the genetic code may carry an embedded signal of non-evolutionary origin.
Their work sparked intrigue — and resistance.
This book revisits the findings of V. sh’Cherbak and M. Makukov with a fresh perspective and a new approach. As a seasoned software engineer and independent researcher in data science and bioinformatics, I present compelling new evidence — evidence that fills a critical gap in their theory and, I argue, settles the case for an embedded signal in the genetic code once and for all.
Whether you’re a scientist, skeptic, or simply curious — I invite you to examine the signal for yourself.

title: Preface
text:
In 2013, two researchers from Al-Farabi Kazakh National University — biophysicist and mathematician Vladimir shCherbak and astronomer Maxim Makukov — published a paper titled “The ‘Wow! signal’ of the terrestrial genetic code” in Icarus, a peer-reviewed journal focused on planetary science and Solar System research. In their 15-page paper, packed with over 15,000 words, they claimed to have discovered an embedded signal within the genetic makeup of life on Earth. While their hypothesis drew immediate attention in fringe online communities and even made appearances on television shows, it was swiftly dismissed by the mainstream scientific community. Terms like “numerology” and “bogus science” were among the more charitable labels applied to their work.
Their decision to condense years of research into a single, dense article led M. Makukov to expand on their ideas through additional channels. He launched a dedicated website, produced explanatory videos on Youtube, and hosted a public Ask Me Anything (AMA) session on Reddit titled “Science AMA Series: I’m Maxim Makukov, a researcher in astrobiology and astrophysics and a co-author of the papers which claim to have identified extraterrestrial signal in the universal genetic code thereby confirming directed panspermia. AMA!”.
The session quickly turned into a heated debate between supporters and skeptics.
In a follow-up article written in 2017, titled “SETI in vivo: testing the we-are-them hypothesis” and published in the International Journal of Astrobiology, the authors addressed critical questions raised after their initial publication. They adopted a more cautious, scientifically grounded tone, aiming to strengthen the credibility of their argument. Despite their efforts, their work was once again met with ridicule, and the broader scientific reception remained dismissive.
Later that year, Vladimir sh’Cherbak sadly passed away. His co-author and former student, Maxim Makukov, subsequently shifted his academic focus toward cosmology.
But were they right?







The aim of this book is to demonstrate, beyond any reasonable doubt, that sh’Cherbak and Makukov were fundamentally correct in their theory. However, I believe they overlooked crucial pieces of the puzzle that would have made their case easier to explain and defend. It took me twelve years of working in information and data science, along with focused training in mathematics, bioinformatics, and genetic data analysis, to uncover those missing pieces.





To the two researchers who led me down this rabbit hole — and made sure I didn’t come back the same.Christoph Kovacs, May 2025

title: Epilogue
text:
“[…] We left our world, explored the stars, and found none like ourselves. Our civilisation thrived for ages, but what is the life of one race, compared to the vast stretches of cosmic time? We knew that one day we would be gone, that nothing of us would survive. So, we left you. Our scientists seeded the primordial oceans of many worlds, where life was in its infancy. The seed codes directed your evolution toward a physical form resembling ours. This body you see before you, which is, of course, shaped as yours is shaped, for you are the end result. The seed codes also contained this message, which we scattered in fragments on many different worlds. […] There is something of us in each of you, and so, something of you in each other. Remember us.”


Humanoid in “The Chase”, Star Trek: The Next Generation
